Posted By: The_Grizz (2/5/2012 12:33:40 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I think what people are forgetting is that it's REPEATABLE exile. Sure, if someone pops it, they get their stuff back, but man, how many times have you bumped into a BU control deck sporting artifact removal? I'd happily pay ![7](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=7&type=symbol) to exile a [Grave Titan](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Grave Titan) any day.  
  
That, and this card is just really neat, and it screams combobait. Red decks get a huge kick out of this, turning their cards like [Traitorous Blood](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Traitorous Blood) into a much more deadly threat (and they're pretty darn significant threads already). Green can ramp up to the card's more expensive ability pretty easily, and can otherwise use it as a hideaway to dump a ton of creatures in the late game for an Overrun or something similar.
posts.html:

Posted By: TherealphatMatt (2/9/2012 1:40:18 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: I've locked down a few games using this; it's very underrated. Most opponents won't waste their artifact removal on it, so you are saving your own creatures from death if you decide to bring them back by destroying the vault yourself later on; or if it's late-game, you're locking down your opponents by exiling each new creach they throw out. I have this and my [Karn Liberated](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Karn Liberated) for late game win-more conditioning.
posts.html:

Its nice, when they try to spot removal your creatures if you have extra mana you can simply exile them. Later on you get an unmake on a stick at ![7](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=7&type=symbol) mana. They will be hesitant to pop this thing when its holding your treasures as well.   
  
And if you happen to have a way to sac this thing yourself, then that gives you options.

posts.post_content: Considering how important this particular artifact is to the story, it's interesting that it has absolutely no abilities that prevent its destruction. Posted By: Hayw00d0909 (1/27/2012 2:41:59 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
This card is a Limited bomb. Sure it takes a while to come online, but once it does, you can keep your opponent off the board. And if they play a critter that's not threatening enough to remove, you have some breathing room to play your own guys. Sure, it's vulnerable to artifact destruction, but outside of Mirrodin, artifact destruction doesn't happen very often.  
  
Everyone's so hyper-focused on building crazy combos with the first and third abilities that they forget that the second ability is straight-forward, easy to use, and just wrecks your opponent.
posts.html:
This card is a Limited bomb. Sure it takes a while to come online, but once it does, you can keep your opponent off the board. And if they play a critter that's not threatening enough to remove, you have some breathing room to play your own guys. Sure, it's vulnerable to artifact destruction, but outside of Mirrodin, artifact destruction doesn't happen very often.

Everyone's so hyper-focused on building crazy combos with the first and third abilities that they forget that the second ability is straight-forward, easy to use, and just wrecks your opponent.

Posted By: Lyriq (4/2/2012 11:34:55 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
TDL-- this is protected by something far more powerful than Indestructibility or Shroud: Faith.  
  
physically, yes. 'any schmuck with a club' could destroy it. But none would DARE to do so, nor even want to try. Innistrad was a very different world than the one we live in now. Before the Dark Ascension at least, the Helvault was the safest place on Innistrad, because the faith in Avacyn alone was strong enough to command reverance from most of society. And I'm sure the priests kept a careful (though probably simple) watch over the Holy Moonstone to prevent Skirsdag cultists and other beings with evil in their hearts from tampering with the Helvault. When Avacyn was strong, probably two robed clerics bearing living wooden and silver holy symbols would be able to defend it against any possible threat.  
  
I think a lot of people were imagining that Mikaeus, the Lunarch must be evil because we as a modern society today seem to be inherently suspicious of most forms of religion and government,... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

posts.post_content:
if there is a use for this card, I am not seeing it. I pulled it from a booster and was all "Holy crap, legendary... artifact..."  
  
and the more i read it, the less useful it seems. 7 mana to exile ONE CREATURE? and if it gets destroyed, they get their stuff back? Why not use the 7 mana for ANYTHING else? Drop an angel/demon/tokens/zombies/ etc. Paramount to the story, yes. Playability? Not really. Use O-Rings.
